column1: #Text=, probably né Alberti ( died 15 June 1585 ) , was a viol player and member of the English Tudor court consort of instruments .
#Text=Of Italian origin , he settled in London in 1545 , remaining in the royal service for the rest of his life .
#Text=As a conscientious churchwarden who compiled unusually detailed records , he is an important source for scholars of late Tudor church history .
#Text=Galliardello was born in Italy – in or near Venice according to one source ; [ 1 ] in Brescia according to others . [ 2 ]
#Text=In either case he was a subject of the Doge of Venice , [ 1 ]
#Text=Brescia being a Venetian possession in the 16th century . [ 3 ]

#Text=The Venetian dominions were at the time the centre of the manufacture of string instruments , and consorts of viols originated there , becoming established in the rest of Europe in succeeding decades . [ 4 ]
#Text=In 1542 Galliardello is recorded as being employed in France by the Cardinal of Lorraine . [ 5 ]

#Text=In 1539 the French ambassador to the court of Henry VIII of England recorded , " The king … now gives himself up to amusement , going to play every night upon the Thames , with harps , chanters and all kinds of music and pastime .

#Text=The historian Brett Usher writes ,  His conscientious drudgery provides historians with vital clues to the development of nonconformist activity in London in the aftermath of the vestiarian controversy which divided the capital after March 1566 .

#Text=Galliardello became prosperous enough to contribute generously to church funds . [ 8 ] and was praised as of  most good name and fame and godly report of all his neighbours " . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=Lucretia and Frances both married royal musicians , respectively Henry Troches and John Lanier .
#Text=Frances 's son , Nicholas Lanier , became the first Master of the King 's Music . [ 1 ]
#Text=Galliardello died on 15 June at Holy Trinity , where he was buried two days later . [ 1 ]
